<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></p>

<div>


<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">PART I</font></u></b><a name="PartI_102600"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Certain statements
contained in this Form 10-K, including without limitation, statements
containing the words &#147;believes,&#148; &#147;estimates,&#148; &#147;expects&#148; and words of similar
import, constitute &#147;forward looking statements&#148; within the meaning of Section
27A of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 21E of the Securities Exchange
Act of 1934.&#160; Such words and expressions
are intended to identify such forward looking statements, but are not intended
to constitute the exclusive means of identifying such statements.&#160; Such forward looking statements involve known
and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause the actual
results, performance or achievements of the Company, or industry results, to be
materially different from any future results, performance or achievements
expressed or implied by such forward looking statements.&#160; Given these uncertainties, prospective
investors are cautioned not to place undue reliance on such forward looking
statements.&#160; The Company disclaims any
obligation to update any such factors or to publicly announce the results of
any revisions to any of the forward looking statements contained herein to
reflect any events or developments.&#160; See
the Company&#146;s Form 8-K filing dated March 26, 1999, for a more detailed
statement concerning forward looking statements.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item
1.&#160; DESCRIPTION OF BUSINESS</font></b><a name="Item1_DescriptionOfBusiness_102604"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">General</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Spherix
Incorporated (the &#147;Company&#148; or &#147;Registrant&#148;), a Delaware corporation, was
founded in 1967.&#160; The Company consists of
a biotechnology segment (&#147;BioSpherix&#148;) and an information services segment (&#147;InfoSpherix&#148;).&#160; At the May 2005 annual meeting shareholders
approved the establishment of InfoSpherix as a wholly-owned subsidiary of
Spherix, which took effect January 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The principal
executive offices of the Company are located at 12051 Indian Creek Court,
Beltsville, Maryland 20705, and its telephone number is (301) 419-3900.&#160; The Company&#146;s Common Stock trades on the
NASDAQ Global Market system under the symbol SPEX.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Available
Information</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our principal
Internet address is www.spherix.com.&#160; We
make available free of charge on www.spherix.com our annual, quarterly and
current reports, and amendments to those reports, as soon as reasonably
practicable after we electronically file such material with, or furnish it to,
the Securities and Exchange Commission (&#147;SEC&#148;).</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">BioSpherix</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">This division is
the Company&#146;s biotechnology research and development arm, dedicated to
developing proprietary products with a view toward commercial
applications.&#160; The Company has
accumulated a number of patents on the products and processes developed by
BioSpherix.&#160; As set forth below, these
products are in the development stage and will require substantial additional
investment to bring any of these products to market.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Tagatose as a
Low-Calorie, Full-Bulk Sweetener.</font></u>&#160; Spherix has patented the use of a naturally
occurring sugar, tagatose, as a low-calorie, full-bulk sweetener.&#160; It is a true sugar that looks, feels, and
tastes like table sugar.&#160; The Company has
developed and patented a method for making tagatose from whey or lactose.&#160; Whey is a waste product from cheese
manufacturing.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Firm has been
developing its sweetener since receiving a U.S. patent for its use and
manufacture as a low-calorie sweetener in 1988, which patent expired August 29,
2006.&#160; The Company received two U.S.
patents for its tagatose production process in 1991 and 1992, which both expire
July 19, 2009.&#160; It has received a number
of foreign patents corresponding to these three and other U.S. patents.&#160; These countries include Canada and Japan,
both large potential markets.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In January 1997,
the Company completed a license agreement with Arla Foods Ingredients amba (&#147;Arla&#148;)
(formerly MD Foods Ingredients amba, &#147;MDFI&#148;) of Denmark for the exclusive,
worldwide rights to market and distribute tagatose as a food and beverage
ingredient in return for a non-refundable up-front payment and fees on net
sales of the sugar for these purposes.&#160;
Arla manufactures a wide variety of dairy products, foods and food
ingredients; it ranks as one of the largest dairy products manufacturers in the
world.&#160; Arla operates cheese plants
producing large amounts of whey as a by-product.&#160; The License Agreement and an amendment
thereto provide Arla the world-wide right to manufacture and sell tagatose for
food uses, and the right to manufacture tagatose for all uses.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='2',FILE='C:\fc\9295719694_D11529_1954770\5660-1-dc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 09:57 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A panel of experts
retained by Arla declared tagatose as Generally Recognized As Safe (&#147;GRAS&#148;) on
April 11, 2001, permitting sale of tagatose as a food ingredient in the
U.S.&#160; The U.S. Food and Drug Administration
(&#147;FDA&#148;) issued a &#147;no objection&#148; letter on October 25, 2001.&#160; Tagatose was recommended by the Joint FAO/WHO
Expert Committee on Food Additives (JECFA) panel in June 2001 to its many
member countries for use in foods, and in June 2004, JECFA removed its former
limit on daily consumption of tagatose.&#160;
In 2003, approval was obtained in South Korea.&#160; In April 2004, tagatose was approved by the
Food Standards Australia New Zealand (&#147;FSANZ&#148;), the food health and safety
agency for Australia and New Zealand.&#160; In
December 2005, tagatose was approved in the European Union.&#160; Arla has begun the approval process for
tagatose in Canada, Japan and Mexico.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The U.S. FDA
approved Arla&#146;s recommended caloric value of 1.5 kilocalories per gram,
permitting labeling of products containing it as &#147;reduced calorie&#148; in the U.S.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2002, Arla
formed a 50/50 joint venture with Nordzucker, a German sugar producer, for the
manufacture and sale of tagatose.&#160; The
joint venture factory was capable of producing 1,200 metric tons per year.&#160; At present Arla believes it has produced a
sufficient backlog of inventory to satisfy its needs for the foreseeable future
based on current demand, and accordingly has stopped production at its pilot
plant until there is a sufficient increase in the demand for tagatose.&#160; To date, Spherix has earned minimal royalties
from Arla and given the cessation of production by Arla, Spherix does not
currently expect to receive any future royalties.&#160; With Spherix&#146;s efforts focusing on the
non-food potentials of Naturlose, the Company is pursing the possibility of
recovering its technology from Arla or securing other production options.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Spherix retains
the rights to the non-food uses to tagatose.&#160;
The Company has discovered and patented a number of health and medical
uses for its product, which it has branded &#147;Naturlose&#174;&#148; for uses in health and
medicine as outlined below.&#160; A priority
among these patented uses is the use of Naturlose in treating Type 2 diabetes.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Treatment
for Type 2 Diabetes.</font></i>&#160;
Trials at the University of Maryland School of Medicine have found
tagatose effective as a treatment of Type 2 diabetes in humans.&#160; In addition to alleviating symptoms of this
major disease, over the one-year trial, all subjects lost weight at physician-approved
rates and showed a significant increase in the desirable type of cholesterol,
HDL.&#160; Other than for initial laxation at
high doses (45 to 75 grams per capita per day), accommodated in about two
weeks, no untoward effects were found in any of the research.&#160; In addition, the studies found that Naturlose
produced no rise in blood glucose or insulin levels in diabetic or normal
subjects.&#160; Naturlose taken before the
consumption of glucose produced a blunting effect on the otherwise normally
expected rise in blood glucose.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In late 2005, the
FDA gave BioSpherix permission to begin a Phase 3 clinical trial for Naturlose
as a stand-alone drug to treat diabetes.&#160;
Since then, BioSpherix&#146;s research and development (R&amp;D) activity has
been focused primarily on planning and instituting the Phase 3 trial. The Phase
3 clinical trial is the last major test, if successful, before requesting drug
approval.&#160; The Company has negotiated two
agreements with contract research organizations (CRO) to conduct the trial, and
has retained Environ International, an FDA regulatory consultant, to guide the
trial.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has
completed the dose range-finding study and will now proceed with recruiting
patients for the trial, which will take place in Australia and the United
States.&#160; The first participants are expected
to begin the Phase 3 clinical trial in April 2007.&#160; More than 300 subjects from the United States
and abroad, representing the demographic mix in the U.S., will receive oral
doses of Naturlose to test its ability to treat Type 2 diabetes.&#160; A Phase 3 clinical trial, which gathers
evidence regarding effectiveness and safety, is needed to evaluate the overall
benefit-risk relationship of new drugs proposed to the FDA.&#160; The Company believes its chances for a successful
outcome are enhanced by the widely demonstrated safety of the product; lack of
safety being the primary cause for failure of most drug candidates.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Anti-plaque
Agent</font></i>:<i>&#160; </i>In 2005, the Company contracted
with the University of Maryland School of Dentistry to conduct human clinical
trials on the oral anti-plaque efficacy of Naturlose.&#160; The study demonstrated tagatose to be much
more resistant to oral bacteria, which form plaque, than is sorbitol, a sugar
substitute that is widely used in oral care products.&#160; The study suggested ways of modifying the
Naturlose product to effect desired plaque reduction.&#160; Such modifications have been made, and the
Company has arranged with the University of Maryland School of Dentistry to
conduct a trial of Naturlose toothpaste formulated by the Company in an attempt
to establish an anti-plaque claim for the toothpaste.&#160; The clinical trial started in early 2007.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">3</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='3',FILE='C:\fc\9295719694_D11529_1954770\5660-1-dc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 09:57 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Anti-hyperglycemic
Agent.</font></i>&#160; Tagatose
functions as an anti-hyperglycemic agent to prevent the formation of
advanced glycosylation end-products, which is one of the major causes of aging.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Increasing
the shelf life of stored blood, platelets and medicinal proteins.</font></i>&#160; The outsourced project seeking to establish
the use of Naturlose to extend the shelf-life of blood fractions and various
other medical products has been suspended as BioSpherix concentrates on the
Type 2 diabetes trial.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Anemia
and Hemophilia Treatment</font></i>.&#160;
Naturlose has been shown to improve blood factors indicating that
tagatose may be useful as a drug or drug adjuvant in the treatment of anemia
and hemophilia.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Increased
Fertility and Improved Fetal Development Drug.</font></i>&#160; Naturlose may increase the fertility of
humans and other animals, to effect higher percentages of live fetuses, and to
cause those fetuses to be heavier, but within normal bounds, than those of
human or animal controls.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Preservative
of Human Organs.</font></i>&#160;
Naturlose has shown potential for use in the transplanting and storage
of human organs to protect against cyto-oxidation and toxic chemicals.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Prototypes of
Naturlose-based mouthwash, cough syrup, and a fiber digestive aid have been
developed by BioSpherix.&#160; Other projects
are in the conceptual stage.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">All of the
potential uses mentioned above require further clinical trial studies and
regulatory approval before they can be brought to market.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Capital for
Development</font></u>.&#160; While the
products under development show promise, continued progress is dependent upon
many factors, including, but not limited to, the Company&#146;s having sufficient
funds and resources to pursue them.&#160; Over
its history, the Company has supported its research and development in part by
using funds generated by InfoSpherix; however, due to the capital needs of
InfoSpherix, and bank covenants restrictions, InfoSpherix may not be able to
support the activities of BioSpherix.&#160;
Funds have also been raised from private placements of Company stock and
warrants, some of the proceeds of which have been used to increase the state of
development, market penetration and sales of the products mentioned above.&#160; The Company believes that it will require
substantial amounts of additional capital to develop and bring its BioSpherix
products to market.&#160; In order to fully
develop, manufacture, distribute and sell Naturlose for these purposes, the
Company is seeking to raise funds and will also seek a relationship with a
major pharmaceutical company.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">BioSpherix revenue
accounted for less than 1% of the Company&#146;s total revenue in 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">InfoSpherix
Incorporated</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In January 2006,
the InfoSpherix business started operating as a wholly-owned subsidiary of
Spherix Incorporated under the name &#147;InfoSpherix Incorporated.&#148;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">InfoSpherix</font> professionals design and operate contact centers,
websites, and field kiosks providing information management and materials to
the public on various socially beneficial subjects, as well as other
information services, such as reservations and tourism.&#160; InfoSpherix focuses on those clients who are
looking to leverage technology in the ever-advancing world of information
management.&#160; InfoSpherix researches,
collects, organizes and disseminates information by providing customized
contact center services combining advanced data collection systems, expert
decision support systems, tele-support utilizing live operators, and advanced
telecommunication technologies such as Interactive Voice Response (&#147;IVR&#148;).&#160; InfoSpherix answers millions of calls
annually from professionals and the public nationwide.&#160; It operates a contact center in Cumberland,
Maryland and a second contact center in Carmel, Indiana.&#160; During 2006, the operations of the Rapid
City, South Dakota contact center were relocated to Carmel, Indiana.&#160; All contact centers efficiently manage and
track high volumes of data.&#160; Coupling
InfoSpherix&#146;s expert staff with its advanced technologies results in an
effective system to collect and disseminate large amounts of information.&#160; The Company also provides reservation
services for campgrounds and other parks via its ReserveWorld business
line.&#160; Since 1998, InfoSpherix has grown
its government park reservation business from one contract to seventeen park
reservation contracts.&#160; InfoSpherix is
one of only two major companies in this market.&#160;
In 2006, Spherix won a new park reservation contract, won the re-compete
on two park reservation contracts, and will be the subcontractor on
another.&#160; InfoSpherix&#146;s reservation
business accounted for 64% of the Company&#146;s revenue in 2006.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">4</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='4',FILE='C:\fc\9295719694_D11529_1954770\5660-1-dc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 09:57 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In October 2006,
the Company agreed to a $6 million settlement to end its longstanding legal
dispute with the U.S. Department of Agriculture over the government&#146;s award of
a national park and reservation contract to ReserveAmerica.&#160; The Company operated the National Park
Service contract for nine years; revenue recognized was $4.0 million, $4.0
million and $3.9 million for the years ended December 31, 2006, 2005 and 2004,
respectively, or 16%, 17% and 17% of total revenue for each year.&#160; The Company&#146;s National Park Service contract
ended January 23, 2007.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">InfoSpherix
accounted for substantially all of the Company&#146;s revenue in 2006.&#160; Most of InfoSpherix&#146;s revenue traditionally
has been generated by a few large government contracts.&#160; See Note 1, &#147;Concentrations,&#148; of the Notes to
the consolidated Financial Statements included herein pursuant to Part II of
this Form 10-K.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Government
Contracts</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">See Note 10, &#147;Commitment
and Contingencies &#151; <i>Government Contracts</i>,&#148;
of the Notes to the Financial Statements included herein pursuant to Part II,
Item 8 of this Form 10-K, which information is incorporated herein by
reference.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Government
contracts typically have terms and conditions which, while providing annual or
multi-year terms, subject them to termination upon convenience or default.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Industry
Segments</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">See Note 13, &#147;Information
by Business Segment,&#148; of the Notes to the Financial Statements included herein
pursuant to Part II, Item 8 of this Form 10-K for industry segment information
of the Company, which information is incorporated herein by reference.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Market
Concentration</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2006, 2005,
and 2004, essentially all of the Company&#146;s revenue was generated by
InfoSpherix.&#160; The Company&#146;s business
operations are usually dependent upon substantial revenue from a select group
of customers.&#160; In 2006, 2005, and 2004,
revenue from the U.S. Government, the State of Michigan and the State of
Maryland each accounted for more than 10% of total Company revenue.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">It is currently
expected that revenue from the U.S. Government, the State of Michigan, the
State of Maryland, and the State of Ohio will each account for more than 10% of
total Company revenue in 2007.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Patents and Trademarks</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has
established a strong worldwide patent position for tagatose.&#160; These patents and other significant Company
patents are detailed in the following table:</font></p>

 <tr bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="18%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:18.14%;">

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 1.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">*&nbsp;&nbsp;Licensed to
Arla Foods.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Trademarks</font></u>.&#160; The Company has trademarked its name, &#147;Spherix,&#148;
&#147;ReserveWorld,&#148; its reservation system, &#147;FlyCracker,&#148; its safe-for-humans
pesticide, &#147;Naturlose,&#148; for non-food uses of tagatose, and &#147;BioSpherix.&#148;&#160; It retains trademarks on its original name, &#147;Biospherics,&#148;
and a former subsidiary, &#147;Vitalian Corp.&#148;</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">With respect to
all of its inventions, the Company has received approximately 130 patents,
including foreign issues.&#160; It has several
patents pending and many additional invention disclosures.&#160; In addition to its strong patent position,
the Company relies on the common law protection of such information as trade
secrets and on confidentiality agreements to protect the value of these assets.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Seasonality</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Revenue from
reservation and tourism services is greatest in the spring and summer when
vacation planning is the heaviest.&#160;
Revenue from other sources tends to be more evenly spread throughout the
year, although the fourth quarter is historically the low period of the year.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Sales
Backlog</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 3.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Sales backlog, consisting
of both funded and unfunded amounts, at December 31, 2006 and 2005, were as
follows (in $000s):</font></p>

  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.4%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="9%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:9.1%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">Current</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.4%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As previously
noted, the Company agreed to a $6 million settlement of its longstanding legal
dispute over the award of the NRRS contract to ReserveAmerica.&#160; As a result the Company&#146;s National Park
Service contract ended January 23, 2007.&#160;
Despite the loss of the National Park Service contract, the Company has
developed a successful niche in providing government campground reservation
services, growing from one to 17 reservation contracts over the past nine years
and won the re-compete on two of its state reservation contracts.&#160; The Company will continue to pursue its
expansion into the state campground reservation niche.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Competition</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">InfoSpherix</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The information
systems industry is subject to rapid and significant technological change.&#160; The Company is in competition with other
information services companies across the nation.&#160; Many of these competitors have substantially
greater financial and technical resources than the Company.&#160; While acknowledging strong competition from
other information services firms, the Company has developed a specialized niche
by concentrating on high quality, </font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">6</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='6',FILE='C:\fc\9295719694_D11529_1954770\5660-1-dc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 09:57 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">personalized service combined with computerization for
efficiency and cost-effectiveness.&#160; The
Company has established a reputation for rapidly starting up information
projects to meet its clients&#146; critical needs, while not compromising high
quality and reasonable pricing.&#160; The
Company has also established a successful niche in government campground
reservation services and is now one of only two major suppliers of campground
services in the U.S.&#160; The other major
supplier is IAC/InterActiveCorp&#146;s ReserveAmerica, a subsidiary of
Ticketmaster.&#160; Over the last three years,
the Company has invested over $3 million in computer and telephony systems and
nearly $3 million in the development of specialized computer software products
to improve its competitive position.&#160; The
Company continues to upgrade and enhance those systems.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">BioSpherix</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Competitors of
BioSpherix are numerous and include, among others, major pharmaceutical,
chemical, consumer, and biotechnology companies, specialized firms,
universities and other research institutions.&#160;
The Company&#146;s competitors may succeed in developing technologies and
products that are more effective than any that are being developed by the
Company, and that could render the Company&#146;s technology and potential products
obsolete and noncompetitive.&#160; Many of
these competitors have substantially greater financial and technical resources
and production and marketing capabilities than the Company.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Research
and Development</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">BioSpherix
expenditures for research and development were approximately $884,000,
$288,000, and $196,000 in 2006, 2005, and 2004, respectively.&#160; These expenditures were incurred primarily in
the ongoing efforts to commercialize Naturlose, including its development for
drug uses and improved production processes.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Governmental
Regulation</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The business
activities of the Company are subject to a variety of Federal and state
compliance, licensing, and certification requirements.&#160; Management believes that the Company is, and
has been at all times, in full compliance with Federal and state environmental
protection and worker safety laws.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company is
also required to comply with the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002.&#160; On September 21, 2005, the SEC announced the
extension of the compliance dates of Section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act for
non-accelerated filers.&#160; Under the
extension, non-accelerated filers, such as Spherix, will begin to comply with
the internal control over financial reporting requirements for the first fiscal
year ending on or after December 15, 2007.&#160;
The Company anticipates that the cost of implementing Section 404 over
the next two years could have a material impact on the results of operations.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Environment</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Compliance with
current federal, state and local provisions regulating the discharge of
materials into the environment, or otherwise relating to the protection of the
environment, has not had, and in the opinion of management will not have, a
material effect on the Company&#146;s financial position, results of operations,
capital expenditures, cash flows or competitive position.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Employees</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2006, the
Company employed an average of 588 individuals on a full- or part-time
basis.&#160; Of this total, approximately 344
were full-time employees.&#160; The Company&#146;s
employees are not currently unionized, and management believes that its
relation with the Company&#146;s employees are harmonious.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Geographic
Areas</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">InfoSpherix&#146;s
business is, and has been, based in the United States.&#160; Accordingly, InfoSpherix revenue is entirely
from U.S.-based operations.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">7</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='7',FILE='C:\fc\9295719694_D11529_1954770\5660-1-dc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 09:57 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item
1A.&#160; RISK FACTORS</font></b><a name="Item1a_RiskFactors_102646"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Any of the risk
factors we describe below could severely harm our business, financial condition
and operating results.&#160; The market price
of our common stock could decline if one or more of these risks and
uncertainties develop into actual events.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">RISKS RELATED TO OUR BUSINESS</font></b><a name="RisksRelatedToOurBusiness_102648"></a></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">WE CONTINUE
TO BE DEPENDENT ON OUR INFORMATION SERVICES DIVISION FOR ALL OF OUR REVENUE</font></b>.&#160; In each of 2006 and 2005, our information
services segment accounted for nearly 100% of our revenue.&#160; Despite licensing tagatose in 1996 for food
and beverage use, our principal biotechnology product, we have yet to receive
any substantial royalties from the sales of tagatose by our licensee.&#160; We are actively pursuing various non-food
uses of Naturlose, including as a treatment for Type 2 diabetes.&#160; Thus, we have incurred substantial and
continuing losses in our biotechnology segment which have adversely affected
our overall financial results.&#160; If we
continue to be unsuccessful in commercializing our biotechnology products, our
financial results will continue to be adversely affected to the detriment of
our stock price.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">OUR
LARGEST INFORMATION SERVICES CONTRACT WAS AWARDED TO A COMPETITOR.</font></b>&#160; In October 2006, the Company agreed to a $6
million settlement to end its longstanding legal dispute with the U.S.
Department of Agriculture over the government&#146;s award of the National
Recreation Reservation Service (NRRS) contract to ReserveAmerica, a
Ticketmaster subsidiary.&#160; The Company&#146;s
National Park Service contract ended January 23, 2007.&#160; The National Park Service contract contributed
$4.0 million in revenue for each of the years ended December 31, 2005 and
2006.&#160; We will need to replace it with
other work to avoid an adverse impact on our financial results.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">OUR
INFORMATION SERVICES BUSINESS COULD BE ADVERSELY AFFECTED BY SIGNIFICANT CHANGES
IN THE CONTRACTING OR FISCAL POLICIES OF THE U.S. FEDERAL GOVERNMENT.</font></b>&#160; We derive substantial revenue from contracts
with the U.S. federal government and we believe that the success and
development of our business will continue to depend on our successful
participation in U.S. federal government contract programs.&#160; Accordingly, changes in U.S. federal
government contracting policies could directly affect our financial
performance.&#160; Among the factors that
could have a material adverse affect on our U.S. federal government contracting
business are:</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>budgetary
constraints affecting U.S. federal government spending generally, or specific
departments or agencies in particular, and changes in fiscal policies or
available funding;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>technological
developments;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>U.S.
federal governmental shutdowns and other potential delays in the government
appropriations process;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>delays
in the payment of our invoices by government payment offices due to problems
with, or upgrades to, government information systems, or for other reasons;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>competition
and consolidation in the information services industry; and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>general economic
conditions.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">OUR
INFORMATION SERVICES BUSINESS IS RELIANT ON TECHNOLOGY.</font></b>&#160; We have devoted significant resources to
developing and acquiring specialized hardware and software in our information
services business.&#160; In order to remain
competitive, we must continue to select, invest in, acquire and develop new and
enhanced technology on a timely ba-sis.&#160;
We may not be successful in these efforts or in anticipating
developments in technology.&#160; In addition,
competitors could develop similar applications.&#160;
Third parties could independently develop similar technology, obtain
unauthorized access to our proprietary technology or misappropriate technology
to which we have granted access.&#160; Failure
to remain current with technology or misappropriation of our technology could
adversely affect our ability to compete for information services business and
could lead to reduced business and reduced financial results.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">WE HAVE
NOT YET SUCCESSFULLY COMMERCIALIZED NATURLOSE.</font></b>&#160; We are in the process of attempting to
develop other uses of tagatose, under the brand name Naturlose, in non-food
products such as a treatment for diabetes, toothpaste, mouthwash, and
over-the-counter and pharmaceutical drugs.&#160;
Efforts are presently limited to the Type 2 diabetes clinical trial and
toothpaste developments because of cash limitations.&#160; To date, we have yet to secure any
substantial revenue from Naturlose sales.&#160;
One of the hurdles we will have to overcome is that our foreign licensee
for tagatose (which has the right to manufacture tagatose) does not currently
have sufficient capacity to manufacture enough tagatose to supply both food and
nonfood markets if such markets mature and grow.&#160; Failure to successfully commercialize
Naturlose may adversely affect our stock price.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">8</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='8',FILE='C:\fc\9295719694_D11529_1954770\5660-1-dc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 09:57 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">OTHER
BIOTECH PRODUCTS ARE STILL IN THE DEVELOPMENT STAGE.</font></b>&#160; We are developing other biotech
products.&#160; None of these have been
developed to a stage where any significant revenue has been generated.&#160; Development of products will require
significant additional research and development.&#160; Such additional effort will require
substantial funding which may not be available to us.&#160; Further, our research and development
activities may not result in any saleable products.&#160; It is also possible that we will license or
seek an affiliation with a third party to bring some products to market.&#160; In such an event, we would likely have
minimal control over the manufacture and marketing of such products.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">DEVELOPMENT
OF ANY BIOTECH PRODUCTS WILL DEPEND ON OBTAINING FDA AND FOREIGN REGULATORY
APPROVALS.</font></b>&#160; Development
of new products is subject to extensive regulation by governmental regulatory
authorities in the United States and other countries.&#160; These rigorous regulatory approval processes
can take five to ten years or more and require the expenditure of substantial
resources.&#160; We may not be able to obtain
the necessary approvals for clinical testing or for the marketing of
products.&#160; Continuing failure to
commercialize biotechnology products may adversely affect our financial results
and stock price.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">OUR
SUCCESS WILL DEPEND, IN PART, ON OUR ABILITY TO OBTAIN AND MAINTAIN PATENT
PROTECTION FOR OUR PRODUCTS.</font></b>&#160;
We have several patents for tagatose and other products under
development.&#160; We may not be able to
obtain additional patents.&#160; Further,
future patents may not be held valid if subsequently challenged.&#160; Failure to obtain and maintain patent
protection for our biotechnology products may further delay or eliminate our
ability to commercialize such products, which may adversely affect our
financial results and stock price.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">WE HAVE
SUSTAINED LOSSES IN THE PAST AND WE MAY SUSTAIN LOSSES IN THE FUTURE.</font></b>&#160; We have incurred losses in prior years,
including the years 2005 and 2004. Our net losses for the years ended December
31, 2005 and 2004 were $2.8 million and $2.8 million, respectively.&#160; Our net income for the year ended December
31, 2006, included $6 million from the U.S. Department of Agriculture settlement.&#160; We may not return to profitable operations.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">WE MAY
NOT BE ABLE TO OBTAIN ADDITIONAL FINANCING THAT WE WILL NEED.&#160; </font></b>During 2006, our working
capital increased by $7.7 million, largely as a result of proceeds from the
U.S. Department of Agriculture settlement and proceeds from stock
issuances.&#160; In recent years, we have
funded our operations through private placements of our common stock and
through the exercise of warrants issued in connection with such private placement
transactions.&#160; We believe that we will
need to raise additional funding to continue to finance our product development
operations.&#160; We may not be able to obtain
additional financing on acceptable terms, or at all.&#160; Failure to obtain required financing may
cause us to curtail or cease our operations.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">WE MAY
NOT BE ABLE TO RETAIN OUR KEY EXECUTIVES AND PERSONNEL. </font></b>&#160;As a small company, our success depends on the
services of key employees in executive and other positions.&#160; None of our key employees have employment
agreements.&#160; The loss of the services of
one or more of such employees could have a material adverse effect on us.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">WE FACE
INTENSE COMPETITION BY COMPETITORS IN BOTH DIVISIONS.</font></b>&#160; Our competitors in the information services
business are numerous.&#160; Many of our
competitors have significantly greater financial, marketing and distribution
resources than we do.&#160; Our principal
information services competitor, ReserveAmerica, is a division of Ticketmaster
which is a subsidiary of IAC/InterActive Corp., a significantly larger public
company than Spherix.&#160; Our competitors
may succeed in developing or marketing technologies and biotechnology products
that are more effective than ours.</p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">RISKS RELATED TO OWNERSHIP OF OUR COMMON STOCK</font></b><a name="RisksRelatedToOwnershipOfOurCommo_102816"></a></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">THE PRICE
OF SPHERIX&#146;S COMMON STOCK HAS BEEN HIGHLY VOLATILE DUE TO SEVERAL FACTORS WHICH
WILL CONTINUE TO EFFECT THE PRICE OF OUR STOCK.</font></b>&#160; Our common stock has traded as low as $1.18
and as high as $3.92 between January 2, 2006 and December 29, 2006. Some of the
factors leading to this volatility include:</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">9</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='9',FILE='C:\fc\9295719694_D11529_1954770\5660-1-dc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 09:57 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>relatively
small amounts of our stock trading on any given day;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>fluctuations
in our operating results;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>announcements
of technological innovations or new products which we or our competitors make;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>developments
with respect to patents or proprietary rights.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">CORNELL
CAPITAL PARTNERS WILL PAY LESS THAN THE MARKET PRICE AND WILL HAVE AN INCENTIVE
TO SELL ITS SHARES, WHICH MAY CAUSE OUR STOCK PRICE TO DECLINE.</font></b>&#160; Cornell Capital Partners will purchase shares
of our common stock pursuant to the Standby Equity Distribution Agreement
(SEDA) at a purchase price that is less than the then-prevailing market price
of our common stock.&#160; Cornell Capital
Partners will have an incentive to immediately sell any shares of our common
stock that it purchases pursuant to the SEDA to realize a gain on the
difference between the purchase price and the then-prevailing market price of
our common stock.&#160; To the extent Cornell
Capital Partners sells its common stock, the common stock price may decrease.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">NEW
SHAREHOLDERS WILL EXPERIENCE SIGNIFICANT DILUTION FROM OUR SALE OF SHARES UNDER
THE SEDA.</font></b>&#160; The sale of
shares pursuant to the SEDA will have a dilutive impact on our
stockholders.&#160; As a result, our net
income per share could decrease in future periods, and the market price of our
common stock could decline.&#160; In addition,
the lower our stock price, the more shares of common stock we will have to
issue under the SEDA.&#160; If our stock price
is lower, then our existing stockholders would experience greater dilution.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">OUR
COMMON STOCK WILL BE DELISTED FROM NASDAQ GLOBAL MARKET SYSTEM IF WE FAIL TO
COMPLY WITH CONTINUED LISTING STANDARDS.</font></b>&#160; We were previously advised that we were in
danger of our common stock being delisted from the NASDAQ Global Market due to
our stockholders&#146; equity falling below the $10 million minimum
requirement.&#160; At December 31, 2006, the
Company&#146;s shareholder&#146;s equity was $14.6 million.&#160; If at some point we are unable to meet the
listing standards, we intend to apply to list our common stock on the NASDAQ
Capital Market.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">DIVIDENDS
ON OUR COMMON STOCK ARE NOT LIKELY.&#160; </font></b>We
intend to retain future earnings, if any, in order to provide funds for use in
the operation and expansion of our business and for further research and
development.&#160; Accordingly, we do not
anticipate paying cash dividends on our common stock in the foreseeable
future.&#160; Investors must look solely to
appreciation in the market price of the shares of our common stock to obtain a
return on their investment.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">BECAUSE
OF THE RIGHTS AGREEMENT AND &#147;ANTI-TAKEOVER&#148; PROVISIONS IN OUR CERTIFICATE OF
INCORPORATION AND BYLAWS, A THIRD PARTY MAY BE DISCOURAGED FROM MAKING A
TAKEOVER OFFER WHICH COULD BE BENEFICIAL TO OUR STOCKHOLDERS.</font></b>&#160; In 2001, we adopted a shareholder rights
plan.&#160; The effect of this rights plan and
of certain provisions of our Certificate of Incorporation, By-Laws, and the
anti-takeover provisions of the Delaware General Corporation Law, could delay
or prevent a third party from acquiring us or replacing members of our board of
directors, even if the acquisition or the replacements would be beneficial to
our stockholders.&#160; These factors could
also reduce the price that certain investors might be willing to pay for shares
of the common stock and result in the market price being lower than it would be
without these provisions.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">INSIDERS
OWN A SIGNIFICANT PORTION OF OUR COMMON STOCK, WHICH COULD LIMIT OUR
STOCKHOLDERS&#146; ABILITY TO INFLUENCE THE OUTCOME OF KEY TRANSACTIONS</font></b>.&#160; As of December 31, 2006, our officers and
directors and their affiliates owned approximately 20% of the outstanding
shares of our common stock.&#160; As a result,
our officers and directors are able to exert considerable influence over the
outcome of any matters submitted to a vote of the holders of our common stock,
including the election of our Board of Directors.&#160; The voting power of these stockholders could
prevent or frustrate attempts to effect a transaction that is in the best
interests of the other stockholders and could also discourage others from
seeking to purchase our common stock, which might depress the price of our
common stock.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">WE
EXPERIENCE QUARTERLY VARIATIONS IN OUR OPERATING RESULTS.</font></b>&#160; We have experienced and expect to continue to
experience quarterly variations in revenue and operating income as a result of
many factors, including the seasonality of our information services business,
timing of customers&#146; budget processes and slowdowns or accelerations of work by
customers.&#160; General work economic
conditions may result in customer deferral of projects or cancellation in
planned expenditures.&#160; These factors may
adversely affect our financial results and our stock price.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">10</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='10',FILE='C:\fc\9295719694_D11529_1954770\5660-1-dc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 09:57 2007' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item
1B.&#160; UNRESOLVED STAFF COMMENTS</font></b><a name="Item1b_UnresolvedStaffComments_102930"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">None.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item
2.&#160; PROPERTIES</font></b><a name="Item2_Properties_102931"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In November 1997,
the Company signed a lease agreement effective May 1, 1998, for 51,625 square
feet of office, call center, research labs, and warehouse space in the same
Beltsville, Maryland, facility previously occupied, under the terms of a lease
that expires on February 28, 2009.&#160; This
facility contains corporate administration, human resources, accounting, sales
and marketing, technical services and warehousing, for support of both InfoSpherix
and BioSpherix, and through September 2005 contained call center operations for
InfoSpherix.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In November 2003,
the Company signed a lease agreement for 31,526 square feet of office and call
center space in Cumberland, Maryland.&#160;
This lease has been extended to coincide with the Company&#146;s move from
this facility to another facility in the area, but no later than February 28,
2008.&#160; The new lease agreement for 32,423
square feet of office and call center space in Frostburg, Maryland, was signed
in February 2007.&#160; The lease is targeted
to commence December 1, 2007, and expire November 30, 2017.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2004, as part
of its acquisition of certain assets of Daksoft, Inc.&#146;s reservation business,
the Company signed an agreement to lease 8,280 square feet of call center space
in Rapid City, South Dakota.&#160; The lease
expired December 31, 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2006, the
Company signed an agreement to lease up to 18,601 square feet of call center
space in Carmel, Indiana, effective April 1, 2006.&#160; The lease expires December 31, 2011.&#160; During 2006, the operations of the Rapid
City, South Dakota facility were transferred to the Carmel, Indiana facility.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2004, the
Company signed an agreement to lease 5,000 square feet of office, research lab
and warehouse space for BioSpherix in Annapolis, Maryland.&#160; The lease expires June 30, 2009.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Throughout 2006,
the Beltsville, Carmel and Annapolis facilities had sufficient capacity.&#160; The Cumberland and Rapid City facilities were
operating at an estimated 75%-90% capacity during the peak months.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item
3.&#160; LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</font></b><a name="Item3_LegalProceedings_102935"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Information
required by this Item 3 is included in Note 10 &#147;Commitments and Contingencies&#148;
of the Notes to Financial Statements, included herein pursuant to Part II of
this Form 10-K.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item
4.&#160; SUBMISSION OF MATTERS TO A VOTE OF
SECURITY HOLDERS</font></b><a name="Item4_SubmissionOfMattersToAVoteO_102936"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">There were no
matters submitted by the Company during the fourth quarter of 2006 to a vote of
security holders through solicitation of proxies or otherwise.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">PART II</font></u></b><a name="PartIi_102937"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item
5.&#160; MARKET FOR REGISTRANT&#146;S COMMON
EQUITY, RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS AND ISSUER PURCHASES OF EQUITY SECURITIES.</font></b><a name="Item5_MarketForRegistrantsCommonE_102939"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s
common stock is traded in the over-the-counter market and is quoted in the
NASDAQ Global Market System under the symbol SPEX.&#160; No cash dividends have been paid.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of March 10,
2007, the number of shareholders of record of the Company&#146;s common stock was
approximately 7,000.&#160; The following table
states the high and low sales prices of the Company&#146;s common stock for each
quarter during the two year period ended December 31, 2006, based on the daily
closing prices as reported on the NASDAQ Global Market System:</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">11</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="32" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:24.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">1.500</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="454" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:340.35pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">

</div>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 1.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company
recognized that, as of June 30, 2005, it was approximately $454,000 short of
meeting NASDAQ&#146;s Global Market listing requirement of maintaining a minimum of
$10,000,000 in shareholders&#146; equity.&#160;
NASDAQ gave the Company until September 1, 2005, to correct this
situation, which the Company achieved through its third quarter results.&#160; However, in anticipation of incurring losses
due to seasonal fluctuations in the InfoSpherix business segment that occur in
the first and fourth quarters of the year, the Company, on July 22, 2005,
entered into a Standby Equity Distribution Agreement (&#147;SEDA&#148;) with Cornell
Capital Partners, L.P. (&#147;Cornell&#148;).&#160;
Under the SEDA, Spherix can require Cornell to purchase up to $4,000,000
of the Company&#146;s common stock over a two-year period following the effective
date, October 12, 2005, of the registration covering the shares of our common
stock to be sold to Cornell.&#160; The SEDA
establishes what is sometimes termed an &#147;equity line of credit&#148; or an &#147;equity
draw-down facility.&#148;&#160; The $4,000,000
facility may be drawn down upon by us in installments, the maximum amount of
each draw down is limited to $350,000.&#160;
For each share of common stock purchased under the SEDA, Cornell will
pay 95% of the lowest volume weighted average price (&#147;VWAP&#148;) of our shares
during the five trading days following our draw down notice to Cornell.&#160; The VWAP used in the calculation is that
reported by Bloomberg, LLC, a third-party reporting service.&#160; In general, the VWAP represents the sum of
the value of all the sales of our common stock for a given day (the total shares
sold in each trade times the sales price per share of the common stock for that
trade), divided by the total number of our shares sold on that day.&#160; We are also committed to pay to Cornell an
amount equal to 5% of each purchase of our common stock made by Cornell under
the SEDA.&#160; Under the terms of the SEDA
agreement, we are not obligated to draw down on the SEDA facility, but once we
satisfy normal conditions for this type of transaction, we have the right to
require Cornell to purchase our common shares under the SEDA.&#160; In connection with the SEDA, we have issued
to Cornell 95,000 shares of our common stock and paid a due diligence fee of
$5,000.&#160; We also paid Yorkville Advisors
Management, LLC, the investment manager for Cornell, a structuring fee of
$15,000, and on each sale under the SEDA we will pay an additional structuring
fee of $500.&#160; Newbridge Securities
Corporation acted as our placement agent for the SEDA, and we paid that firm a
fee of 5,000 shares of our common stock as compensation valued at approximately
$10,000.&#160; We also granted Newbridge
Securities Corporation piggy-back registration rights covering these
shares.&#160; Registration of our common
shares allocated to this facility was completed in October 2005.&#160; During the term of the SEDA, our Officers and
Directors have agreed not to sell any of their shares of our common stock,
except to the extent permitted under Rule 144.&#160;
The number of shares of our common stock issuable to Cornell under the
SEDA is subject to a 9.99% cap on the beneficial ownership that Cornell and its
affiliates may have at the time of each sale (beneficial ownership is to be
calculated in accordance with Section 13(d) of the Exchange Act).&#160; Further, we may not issue more than 19.99% of
our currently outstanding shares under the SEDA unless shareholder approval is
received.&#160; In 2006 and 2005, the Company
sold 819,453 and 310,076 shares under the SEDA agreement for total proceeds of
$1,896,500 and $376,500, respectively.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On February 18,
2004, warrants for 500,000 shares of Common Stock were exercised at $6.91 per
share, compared to the then current market price of $6.76 per share, by an
institutional investor, and the expiration date of the remaining 585,973
warrants was extended until February 25, 2008, at an exercise price of $7.00
per share of common stock.&#160; The remaining
warrants were assigned and transferred to another institutional investor in
2004.&#160; On March 9, 2006, in exchange for
the Company&#146;s agreement to reduce the exercise price to $2.04 per share, the
Investor agreed to exercise the warrants for the full 585,973 shares for total
proceeds of approximately $1.2 million.&#160;
In connection with these warrants, the Investor agreed that it would not
exercise any of the warrants to the extent that it would acquire shares of
Common Stock exceeding 9.9% of the outstanding Common Stock, nor would it
knowingly sell shares to anyone to the extent that their holdings in the
Company would exceed 4.9% of the outstanding Common Stock.&#160; The warrants and shares of Common Stock were
issued in transactions exempt from Registration pursuant to Section 4(2) of the
Securities Act.&#160; The Company has
registered the shares issuable upon exercise of the warrants for resale by the
institutional Investor.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">12</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='12',FILE='C:\fc\92104515294_D11529_1954957\5660-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 10:45 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At December 31,
2006, the Company&#146;s shareholder&#146;s equity was $14.6 million.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has a
share repurchase program in place that initially authorized the purchase of up
to $1,000,000 of the Company&#146;s shares in the open market.&#160; To date, only 34,750 shares aggregating
$160,000 of the Company&#146;s shares have been repurchased.&#160; There was no repurchase activity during 2005
or 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Equity Compensation Plan
Information</font></b></p>

the exercise of options and rights under all of the Company&#146;s existing equity
compensation plans as of December 31, 2006, as well as rights to acquire shares
of Company Common Stock granted to the independent members of the Board of
Directors of the Company.</font></p>

</table>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 13.5pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-13.5pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:6.5pt;position:relative;top:-3.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(1)</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Consists
of stock options issued to the Board of Directors prior to May 12, 2005.</p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Cumulative
Total Return</font></b></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Based upon an initial investment
of $100 on December 31, 2001</font></b></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">with
dividends reinvested</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The following graph
assumes $100 was invested on December&nbsp;31, 2001 in Spherix Common Stock,
the S&amp;P 500 Index and the S&amp;P small cap 600.&#160; It compares the cumulative total return on
each, assuming reinvestment of dividends, for the five-year period ended
December&nbsp;31, 2006.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 7.5pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><img width="623" height="275" src="g56601dei001.gif"></font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 7.5pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">13</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.0%;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="9%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:9.26%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">10,865,583</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  </td>

  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">
