<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item 7.</font></b><b><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</b><a name="Item7_ManagementsDiscussionAndAna_105311"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Overview</font></b></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company operates via two principal segments, BioSpherix and
InfoSpherix.&#160; BioSpherix develops
proprietary products for commercial applications.&#160; InfoSpherix provides contact center
information and reservation services for government and industry.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">InfoSpherix generates substantially all of the Company&#146;s revenue.&#160; In 2006, 2005, and 2004, InfoSpherix
generated substantially all of its revenue from government customers.&#160; The Company has developed a niche in
providing campground and other reservation services via its ReserveWorld
business line, which accounted for approximately 64%, 62%, and 58% of the
Company&#146;s revenue in 2006, 2005, and 2004.&#160;
During 2006, the Company won a reservation contract for the State of
Maine, and the re-compete of the contracts from the States of Indiana and
Minnesota.&#160; The Company&#146;s National Park
Service contract ended January 23, 2007.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">BioSpherix engages in product development, notably tagatose.&#160; The rights to manufacture tagatose have been
licensed to Arla along with the rights to sell tagatose for food and beverage
uses.&#160; Our licensee has not been
successful in marketing tagatose for food and beverage uses and has announced a
cessation of further product manufacturing.&#160;
Accordingly, we have focused our efforts on non-food use of tagatose,
which we will market under the name &#147;Naturlose&#148;.&#160; Our principal efforts have been to explore
whether Naturlose is an effective treatment for Type 2 diabetes.&#160; We are about to commence a Phase 3 clinical
trial for this purpose.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Results
of Operations</font></b><b><font face="Symbol" style="font-weight:bold;">&#190;</font>2006 Compared with
2005</b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2006, the
Company reported a net income of $3.5 million ($0.26 per diluted share) on
revenue of $24.8 million for the year, compared with a net loss of $2.8 million
($0.24 per diluted share) on revenue of $23 million in 2005.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Revenue</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company
experienced a $1.8 million (8%) increase in revenue between years as a result
of InfoSpherix&#146;s State of Pennsylvania campground reservation contract that was
awarded to the Company in 2005 and became operational at the beginning of 2006.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">14</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='14',FILE='C:\fc\92104515294_D11529_1954957\5660-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 10:45 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Direct
Contract and Operating Costs</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Direct contract
and operating costs increased $431,000 (2%) between years with the addition of
the State of Pennsylvania contract.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Selling, General and Administrative</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Selling,
general and administrative expense (&#147;S,G&amp;A&#148;) for 2006 increased by $360,000
(7%) as the result of increased legal costs relating to the Company&#146;s challenge
of the U.S. Department of Agriculture&#146;s award of the NRRS contract to another
competitor, as noted above.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Research
and Development</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Research and
development costs increased $595,000 between years.&#160; The Company is focusing its efforts on the
development of Naturlose as a treatment for Type 2 diabetes.&#160; In 2006, the Company expended approximately
$780,000 in preparation for the Phase 3 clinical trial which is expected to
commence in April 2007.&#160; The Phase 3
clinical trial is expected to take at least two (2) years to complete.&#160; If the Phase 3 clinical trial is successful,
the Company will submit an appropriate drug application to the FDA.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The cost of
preparing for and conducting the Phase 3 trial has substantially increased as
the Company has increased the number of participants and the FDA requested a
change in the form of delivery of the drug to the participants.&#160; The Company estimates that it could expend up
to $5 million in 2007 in furtherance of this trial.&#160; Additional sums will be required to complete
the trial in 2008 and, if successful, to file and pursue the FDA application.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has
also outsourced to others preliminary testing of Naturlose to establish an
anti-plaque claim for toothpaste.&#160; In
2005, the Company contracted with the University of Maryland School of
Dentistry to conduct human clinical trials on the oral anti-plaque efficacy of
Naturlose.&#160; The study demonstrated
tagatose to be much more resistant to oral bacteria, which form plaque, than is
sorbitol, a sugar substitute that is widely used in oral care products.&#160; The study suggested ways of modifying the
Naturlose product to effect desired plaque reduction.&#160; Such modifications have been made, and the
Company has negotiated with the University of Maryland School of Dentistry to
conduct a trial of Naturlose toothpaste formulated by the Company in an attempt
to establish an anti-plaque claim for the toothpaste.&#160; The clinical trial started in early 2007.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Other
Income</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In October 2006,
the Company agreed to a $6 million settlement to end its longstanding legal
dispute with the U.S. Department of Agriculture over the government&#146;s award of
the National Recreation Reservation Service (NRRS) contract to ReserveAmerica,
a Ticketmaster subsidiary.&#160; The Company&#146;s
National Park Service contract ended January 23, 2007.&#160; The National Park Service contract
contributed approximately $4.0 million in revenue for each of the years ended
December 31, 2006 and 2005.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">InfoSpherix
Operations</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The following
schedule summarizes the breakdown of InfoSpherix revenue between government and
commercial contracts (in $000s):</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="68" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:51.35pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">24,831</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="7" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:5.0pt;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="68" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:51.35pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">23,023</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 2.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As noted above,
InfoSpherix revenue for 2006 increased $1.8 million (8%) over that of the prior
year.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">15</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='15',FILE='C:\fc\92104515294_D11529_1954957\5660-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 10:45 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2006, the Company won a reservation contract from the State of
Maine, and the re-compete of the contracts from the States of Indiana and
Minnesota.&#160; The Company&#146;s National Park
Service contract ended January 23, 2007.&#160;
The Company operated the NPRS contract for nine years; revenue
recognized was $4.0 million for each of the years ended December 31, 2006, and
2005, or 16% and 17% of total revenue for each year.&#160; Park reservation contracts during 2006 and
2005 made up over 60% of the Company&#146;s revenue and the Company is one of only
two major suppliers of campground reservation services in the U.S.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Starting October
1, 2005, as part of the cost reduction efforts, the Maryland information center
contracts began operating exclusively in the Company&#146;s Cumberland office
instead of the Beltsville office, and its margins for the fourth quarter of
2005 and for all of 2006 are now consistent with our other contracts.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Currently, the
Company is bidding on several contracts and expects to bid on more contracts
throughout the coming year, although no assurance can be given at this time
that these efforts will result in new business for the Company.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">BioSpherix
Operations</font></b></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">BioSpherix is entitled to high end royalties from Arla&#146;s sales of
tagatose until at least 2011, and, depending upon certain conditions, until
2016.&#160; The payments are net of
accumulated and continuing foreign patent maintenance costs.&#160; -Accumulated patent maintenance costs were
approximately $213,000 at year-end.&#160; We
have earned minimal royalties from Arla in 2006, 2005, and 2004.&#160; While tagatose has been introduced into
several food and beverage products, Arla currently has insufficient sales
volume and manufacturing capacity to produce tagatose at the rate necessary to
generate meaningful royalties.&#160; At
present, Arla believes it has produced a sufficient backlog of inventory to
satisfy its needs for the foreseeable future based on current demand, and
accordingly has stopped production at its plant.&#160; Spherix is also pursing the possibility of
other production options.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company is
focusing its efforts on the development of Naturlose as a treatment for Type 2
diabetes.&#160; In 2006, the Company expended
approximately $780,000 in preparation for the Phase 3 clinical trial which is
expected to commence in April 2007.&#160; The
Phase 3 clinical trial is expected to take at least two (2) years to
complete.&#160; If the Phase 3 clinical trial
is successful, the Company will submit a New Drug Application (NDA) to the
FDA.&#160; Approval would allow the product to
be sold for its intended use to treat Type 2 diabetes.&#160; The Company would seek to partner with or
license a major drug firm for such commercialization.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The cost of
preparing for and conducting the Phase 3 trial has substantially increased as
the FDA has provided more stringent parameters for the trial.&#160; The Company estimates that it could expend up
to $5 million in 2007 in furtherance of this trial.&#160; Additional sums will be required to complete
the trial in 2008 and, if successful, to file and pursue the FDA application.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has
also outsourced to others preliminary testing of Naturlose to establish an
anti-plaque claim for toothpaste.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Sales Backlog</font></b></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s funded and unfunded backlog as of December 31, 2006, was
$57 million, compared to $72 million as of December 31, 2005.&#160; In 2006, the Company won a reservation
contract from the State of Maine, and the re-compete of the contracts from the
States of Indiana and Minnesota.&#160; The NPS
contract ended in January 2007.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Results
of Operations</font></b><b><font face="Symbol" style="font-weight:bold;">&#190;</font>2005 Compared with
2004</b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2005, the
Company reported a net loss of $2.8 million ($0.24 per diluted share) on
revenue of $23.0 million for the year, compared with a net loss of $2.8 million
($0.24 per diluted share) on revenue of $22.3 million in 2004.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Revenue</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Revenue between
years increased $697,000 (3%).&#160; Revenue
from the InfoSpherix Division increased $802,000 (4%) and the BioSpherix
Division&#146;s revenue decreased by $104,000 (82%).&#160;
The increased revenue from the InfoSpherix Division was less than
anticipated as a result of an unexpected temporary funding shortage on one of
our major Federal contracts that lasted for a period of four months until the
Federal Government&#146;s fiscal year ended September 2005, and from hurricanes and
the rise in gasoline prices that impacted reservation sales on our park
reservation contracts during the third quarter of 2005.&#160; The Division also saw a decrease in revenue
of approximately </font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">16</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='16',FILE='C:\fc\92104515294_D11529_1954957\5660-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 10:45 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$2.9 million between years as a result of the decrease
in revenue under the new State of Maryland contract that started November 2004
and the IRS contract that ended in April 2004.&#160;
However, these set-backs were more than off-set by the division&#146;s
continued overall growth from the award of new contracts.&#160; The revenue growth was primarily driven by
contracts such as the Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board that started
in May 2004, the Georgia contract that started in March 2004, and from
increases under existing contracts with the state of Ohio and the Office of
Personnel Management.&#160; The decrease in
BioSpherix revenue was related to the discontinuance of the sale of FlyCracker
in 2004.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Direct
Contract and Operating Costs</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Direct contract
and operating costs increased $863,000 (4%) between years.&#160; This increase included the recognition of a
forward loss provision of $135,000 on one of the Company&#146;s contracts.&#160; The increase is also attributed to
approximately $100,000 in start-up costs related to the new State of Pennsylvania
contract that began in January 2006.&#160;
South Dakota operations operated at a break-even for 2005, up $100,000
from 2004.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Selling, General and Administrative</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Selling,
general and administrative expense (&#147;S,G&amp;A&#148;) for 2005 decreased by $217,000
(4%) from that of the prior year.&#160; In
2005, the Company cut its consulting costs by approximately $265,000, most of
which were related to marketing.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Research
and Development</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Research and
development costs increased $92,000 between years.&#160; In 2004, the BioSpherix Division began a
program of outsourcing development of its patented drug uses of Naturlose.&#160; A research project was funded at the Albert
Einstein College of Medicine to follow up on that institution&#146;s discovery that
Naturlose may lengthen shelf life of stored blood fractions and medicinal
proteins.&#160; In 2005, the Company
contracted with the University of Maryland School of Dentistry to conduct human
clinical trials on the oral anti-plaque efficacy of Naturlose.&#160; The study demonstrated tagatose to be much
more resistant to oral bacteria, which form plaque, than is sorbitol, a sugar
substitute that is widely used in oral care products.&#160; Contrary to earlier laboratory findings by
Spherix, however, a human study at the University of Maryland School of Dentistry
did not show anti-plaque activity.&#160;
Conditions in the mouth may have prevented the desired effect, according
to the University researchers.&#160; Spherix
is following up on corrective suggestions made by the University, and plans to
conduct new human trials.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">InfoSpherix
Operations</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The following
schedule summarizes the breakdown of InfoSpherix revenue between government and
commercial contracts (in $000s):</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="68" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:51.35pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">23,023</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="7" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:5.0pt;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="68" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:51.35pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">22,221</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As noted above,
InfoSpherix revenue for 2005 increased $802,000 (4%) over that of the prior
year.&#160; The increased revenue from the
InfoSpherix Division was less than anticipated as a result of an unexpected
temporary funding shortage on one of our major Federal contracts that lasted
for a period of four months until the Federal Government&#146;s fiscal year ended
September 2005, and from hurricanes and the rise in gasoline prices that
impacted reservation sales on our park reservation contracts during the third
quarter of 2005.&#160; The Division also saw a
decrease in revenue of approximately $2.9 million between years from the
decrease in revenue under the new State of Maryland contract that started
November 2004, and the IRS contract that ended in April 2004.&#160; However, these set-backs were more than
off-set by the division&#146;s continued overall growth.&#160; This revenue growth was primarily driven by
contracts such as the Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board that started
in May 2004, Georgia that started in March 2004, and from increases under
existing contracts such as Ohio and the Office of Personnel Management.&#160; The fourth quarter in particular saw a
significant improvement over the prior year, with an increase in revenue of
$399,000 as a result of increased revenue in the Federal Retirement Thrift
Investment Board contract and a general growth across the board on our existing
reservation contracts.&#160; This combined
with a reduction in direct costs of $139,000 between the fourth quarter of 2005
and 2004, contributed to the $472,000 improvement in operations between
quarters.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">17</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='17',FILE='C:\fc\92104515294_D11529_1954957\5660-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 10:45 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2005, Spherix
won park reservation contracts for Orange County, California, the State of
Pennsylvania, and the State of Michigan.&#160;
The Orange County contract consists of three base years and is valued at
less than half a million.&#160; The State of
Pennsylvania contract is a five-year contract, consisting of one base year and
four option years, valued at approximately $8 million.&#160; The State of Michigan contract is a
continuation of our current contract with the State.&#160; The new contract is for five years, and
consists of three base years plus two option years, valued at approximately $14
million.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In March 2004, the
Company won a one-year, multi-million dollar Federal Retirement Thrift
Investment Board (&#147;FRTIB&#148;) contract with four option years.&#160; Also, on March 1, 2004, the Company purchased
certain assets of Daksoft, Inc. related to its reservation business, which
operates under the name &#147;ReserveIt.&#148;&#160; The
purchase included the acquisition of six additional government reservation
contracts and the intellectual property rights to the name &#147;ReserveIt,&#148; as well
as other assets of the division.&#160; Spherix
purchased the assets for $700,000 plus 43,029 shares of the Company&#146;s common
stock, then trading at $6.699 per share.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2004, the
Company won the re-procurement of the Maryland information center contracts,
which the company has operated since 1998.&#160;
The new contracts are for three years plus two additional option
years.&#160; The combined Maryland contracts
contributed 12% to the Company&#146;s revenue in 2005 and 22% in 2004.&#160; The new contract started on November 1, 2004,
and is subject to a more competitive pricing structure, which was necessary to
win the re-compete.&#160; While Spherix was
not the lowest bidder, the Company&#146;s higher technical scoring resulted in the
Company achieving an overall higher score than the competition.&#160; Management is uncertain as to the long-term
financial impact the price reduction will have over the course of the contract
and believes that the lower rates may encourage the state to outsource more of
its call center needs to Spherix under this contract.&#160; The previous contract initially operated at a
loss during its first year and had matured to a respectable contribution margin
by the time the contract ended in late 2004.&#160;
This increase was gained through the continued outsourcing of more of
the state&#146;s call center needs to Spherix under the contract.&#160; The new contract, which was bid at a lower
contribution margin, is the principal cause for the decrease in operating
income between years.&#160; Starting October
1, 2005, as part of the cost reduction efforts, the Maryland contract began
operating exclusively out of the Company&#146;s Cumberland office instead of the
Beltsville office, and its margins for the fourth quarter were now consistent
with our other contracts.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Revenue from
commercial contracts decreased between years.&#160;
Commercial contracts are typically for shorter terms than government
contracts and that can result in substantial variations in commercial
revenue.&#160; Commercial contracts are being
pursued by the Company, but the Company&#146;s recent history has been that
contracts have been received on a sporadic basis.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">BioSpherix
Operations</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The $104,000
decrease in the BioSpherix revenue from $127,000 to $23,000 between years was
related to the discontinuance of the sale of FlyCracker in 2004.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Sales Backlog</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s
funded and unfunded backlog as of December 31, 2005, was $72 million, compared
to $61 million as of December 31, 2004.&#160;
In 2005, the Company won five-year contracts with the States of
Pennsylvania and Michigan.</font></p>

<h1 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Critical Accounting Estimates</font></b></h1>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The preparation of
financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted
in the United States of America requires management to make estimates and
assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and the
disclosure of the contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the
financial statements and revenue and expenses for the period reported.&#160; Estimates are based upon historical
experience and various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable
under the circumstances.&#160; These estimates
are evaluated periodically and form the basis for making judgments regarding
the carrying values of assets and liabilities and the reported amount of
revenue and expenses.&#160; Actual results may
differ substantially from these estimates.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">18</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='18',FILE='C:\fc\92104515294_D11529_1954957\5660-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 10:45 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Spherix&#146;s critical
accounting policies are those it believes are the most important in determining
its financial condition and results, and require significant subjective
judgment by management as a result of inherent uncertainties.&#160; A summary of the Company&#146;s significant
accounting policies is set out in the notes to the consolidated financial
statements.&#160; Such policies are discussed
below.</font></p>

<h1 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Accounting
for Taxes and Valuation Allowances</font></i></b></h1>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We currently have
significant deferred tax assets, resulting from net operating loss carry
forwards.&#160; These deferred tax assets may
reduce taxable income in future periods.&#160;
Based on the Company&#146;s losses and its accumulated deficit, the Company
has provided a full valuation allowance against the net deferred tax
asset.&#160; A valuation allowance is required
when it is more likely than not that all or a portion of a deferred tax asset
will not be realized.&#160; Cumulative losses
weigh heavily in the overall assessment of valuation allowances.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We expect to
continue to maintain a full valuation allowance on future tax benefits until an
appropriate level of profitability is sustained, or we are able to develop tax
strategies that would enable us to conclude that it is more likely than not
that a portion of our deferred tax assets would be realizable.</font></p>

<h1 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Long-Lived
Assets and Other Intangible Assets</font></i></b></h1>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Long-lived assets
and other intangible assets are reviewed for impairment whenever the carrying
amount of the asset may not be recoverable. An impairment loss is recognized
when the carrying amount of a long-lived asset exceeds the sum of the
undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the asset&#146;s use and eventual
disposition.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">New Accounting Pronouncements</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In June 2006, the
Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#147;FASB&#148;) issued FASB Interpretation No.
48, &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes&#148; (&#147;FIN48&#148;).&#160; The Interpretation clarifies the accounting
for uncertainty in income taxes recognized in an enterprise&#146;s financial
statements in accordance with FASB Statement No. 109, &#147;Accounting for Income
Taxes.&#148;&#160; We are required to adopt FIN 48
effective January 1, 2007.&#160; We are currently
evaluating the impact this interpretation will have on our financial position,
results of operations, and cash flows.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In September 2006,
the FASB issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 157, &#147;Fair
Value Measurements&#148; (&#147;SFAS 157&#148;). &#160;SFAS
157 defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value, and
expands disclosures about fair value measurements.&#160; We are required to adopt SFAS 157 effective
January 1, 2008. We do not expect the adoption of SFAS 157 to have a material
affect on our financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In September 2006,
the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (&#147;SEC&#148;) issued Staff Accounting
Bulletin No. 108 (&#147;SAB 108&#148;).&#160; SAB 108
addresses diversity in practice in quantifying financial statement
misstatements and the potential under current practice for the build up of
improper amounts on the balance sheet.&#160;
The bulletin requires companies to quantify misstatements based on their
impact on each of their financial statements and related disclosures.&#160; We have adopted SAB 108 in connection with
the preparation of our financial statements for the year ended December 31,
2006.&#160; The adoption of SAB 108 did not
have a material impact on our financial position, results of operations or cash
flows.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Liquidity
and Capital Resources</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On March 31, 2006,
the Company entered into a new agreement with Bank of America (&#147;the Bank&#148;) to
establish a line-of-credit (&#147;New Agreement&#148;) for its subsidiary, InfoSpherix
Incorporated, with the outstanding borrowings under the old line of credit
transferred to the new agreement.&#160;
Management considers the establishment of this credit facility for the
subsidiary necessary to ensure timely cash flow for the subsidiary&#146;s
operations.&#160; The New Agreement, which
matures June 30, 2008, provides for borrowings up to $1.5 million, is
collateralized by the subsidiary&#146;s accounts receivables and equipment, and
contains covenants on tangible net worth and funded debt to EBITDA ratios.&#160; Such covenants could have a limiting effect
on the amount of cash that the subsidiary can advance to Spherix.&#160; The interest rate under the Agreement is
based on the LIBOR daily floating rate plus 3% (approximately 8.34% at December
31, 2006).&#160; The Company had no
outstanding borrowings under the Agreement at December 31, 2006, and the total
amount available for future advance to the subsidiary was $1.5 million under
the Agreement.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Working capital as
of December 31, 2006, was $10.9 million, which represents a $7.8 million
increase from working capital of $3.1 million at December 31, 2005.&#160; The increase in working capital between years
was largely related to the U.S. Department of Agriculture settlement.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Spherix expects to
expend up to $5&nbsp;million over the next year in costs related to the
Phase&nbsp;3 clinical trial.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">19</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='19',FILE='C:\fc\92104515294_D11529_1954957\5660-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 10:45 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">InfoSpherix
Incorporated intends to finance its furniture and equipment needs through
financing or leasing arrangements where practicable, including those related to
the start-up costs of new contracts the Company may win.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Cash flow for the
year ended December 31, 2006, reflects a net cash inflow of $8.3 million,
consisting of $6.7 million provided by operating activities, $586,000 provided
by investing activities, and $1 million provided by financing activities.&#160; The increase in cash provided by operating
activities in 2006 from that of the prior year was primarily due to $6 million
settlement with the U.S. Department of Agriculture over the award of the NRRS
contract.&#160; The increase in cash provided
by investing activities was directly related to the expiration of restrictions
on cash that was used as collateral on the Company&#146;s line-of-credit in prior
years, and the increase in cash provided by financing activities was the result
of proceeds raised from the issuance of stock under the SEDA agreement and the
exercise of warrants.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Trends
and Outlooks</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">InfoSpherix</font></b></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The
Company&#146;s National Park Service contract ended January 23, 2007.&#160; The National Park Service contract
contributed approximately $4.0 million in revenue for each of the years ended
December 31, 2006 and 2005.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>In
2006, the Company won the re-compete on its park reservation services to the
States of Indiana and Minnesota and recently won a new state park reservation
contract for the State of Maine and will be a subcontractor on another
contract.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Since
1998, InfoSpherix has grown its government park reservation business from one
contract to 17 government reservation contracts.&#160; InfoSpherix&#146;s reservation business accounted
for over 60% of the Company&#146;s revenue in 2006 and 2005.&#160; InfoSpherix is now one of only two major
suppliers of Government campground reservation services in the U.S.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>On
February 6, 2007, the Company signed an agreement to lease 32,423 square feet
of facility space in Frostburg, Maryland effective December 1, 2007, for use as
a call center to replace the existing Cumberland, Maryland facility.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">BioSpherix</font></b></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>BioSpherix&#146;s
primary emphasis is on a Phase 3 clinical trial to demonstrate that Naturlose
is a successful treatment for Type 2 diabetes.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Costs
of conducting the Phase 3 trial have substantially increased as we have
obtained further direction from the FDA concerning the processes to be employed
in the trials.&#160; The Company is exploring
all of its alternatives to generate sufficient funds to complete the Phase 3
trial, to further develop Naturlose as a diabetes treatment if the Phase 3
trial is successful, and to further commercialize Naturlose for other uses.</p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Contractual
Obligations</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The following
table summarizes the Company&#146;s known contractual obligations at December 31,
2006, and indicates the year payments are due.&#160;
In some cases estimates have been used where the exact amount and/or
timing of the obligation is not presently known.&#160; The table does not include ordinary accounts
payable and payroll type obligations and does not include estimates for future
interest obligation payments under the Company&#146;s bank line of credit noted
above in the Liquidity and Capital Resources sections.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">20</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<div style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><hr size="1" width="160" noshade color="black" align="left" style="width:120.0pt;"></div>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 27.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(1)</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Includes
interest obligations of $40,000 ($33,000 in 2007 and $7,000 in 2008).</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 27.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(2)</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Includes
estimated common area maintenance costs.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 27.0pt;text-indent:-27.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(3)</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Consists
primarily of the estimated amounts on the committed obligations related to the
Phase 3 clinical trial.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">No dividends were
paid in 2006 and none are anticipated in 2007.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item
7A.&#160; QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE
DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK</font></b><a name="Item7a_QuantitativeAndQualitative_113924"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company
manages its debt and its available cash by considering available investment
opportunities, risks, tax consequences and overall financing strategies.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At December 31,
2006, the Company did not have any fixed-rate or variable-rate
indebtedness.&#160; The Company has not
entered into any interest rate swaps or other derivatives with respect to its
indebtedness.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Cash available for
investment is typically invested in short term funds, which generally mature in
30 days, or money-market funds.&#160; In
general, such funds are not subject to market risk because the interest paid on
such funds fluctuates with the prevailing interest rate.&#160; The carrying amounts approximate market
value.&#160; It is the Company&#146;s practice to
hold these investments to maturity.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Assuming year-end
2006 variable rate debt and cash available for investment, a one percent change
in interest rates would impact net interest income by less than $100,000.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item 8.&#160; FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEMENTARY DATA</font></b><a name="Item8_FinancialStatementsAndSuppl_113927"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Financial
statements and supplementary data required by this Item 8 follow.</font></p>

  <p align="right" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">27</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">21</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='21',FILE='C:\fc\92104515294_D11529_1954957\5660-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Apr  2 10:45 2007' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">REPORT
OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM</font></b></p>

<p style="line-height:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Board of Directors and
Shareholders of Spherix Incorporated</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We have audited the
accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Spherix Incorporated (a Delaware
corporation) and subsidiary (the Company) as of December 31, 2006 and 2005, and
the related consolidated statements of operations, changes in stockholders&#146;
equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December
31, 2006.&#160;&#160; These financial statements
are the responsibility of the Company&#146;s management.&#160; Our responsibility is to express an opinion
on these financial statements based on our audits.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We conducted our audits
in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight
Board (United States).&nbsp; Those standards require that we plan and perform
the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial
statements are free of material misstatement.&nbsp; The Company is not required
to have, nor were we engaged to perform an audit of its internal control over
financial reporting.&#160; Our audits included
consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for
designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not
for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company&#146;s
internal control over financial reporting.&#160;
Accordingly, we express no such opinion.&#160;
An audit also includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting
the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting
principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as
evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.&nbsp; We believe that
our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In our opinion, the
consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all
material respects, the financial position of the Company as of December 31,
2006 and 2005, and the results of its operations and its cash flows for each of
the three years in the period ended December 31, 2006 in conformity with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As discussed in Note 1 to
the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, the Company adopted SFAS No.
123R, &#147;<i>Share-Based Payment</i>,&#148; effective January
1, 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">/s/ GRANT THORNTON LLP</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">McLean, Virginia<br>
March 29, 2007</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">22</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Spherix Incorporated</font></b></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Consolidated
</font></b><b>Balance Sheets</b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">As of
December 31, 2006 and 2005</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="border-collapse:collapse;width:100.0%;">
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="73%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:73.96%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="10%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:10.22%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">2006</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">

<p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The accompanying notes to
financial statements are an integral part of these financial statements.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">24</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='24',FILE='C:\fc\90152850125_D11854_1951285\5660-1-dg.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 31 15:29 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Spherix Incorporated</font></b></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Consolidated
</font></b><b>Statements of Changes in
Stockholders&#146; Equity</b></p>

2006, 2005 and 2004</font></b></p>

financial statements are an integral part of these financial statements.</font></p>

  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>

  </td>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The accompanying notes to
financial statements are an integral part of these financial statements.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">26</font></p>
